attributes.comment:
The proposed fee increase is too drastic. The current funding gap of the USCIS
is largely created by the inefficiency of the operation management and the
outdated rules regarding the approval process. This created two problems.

1. The pending applications such as I-485 -- adjustment to immigrant status --
have a long waiting period. This forces the applicants to apply for EAD cards
and Advance parole or renew their H-1B applications during this time. This
increases the workload of the USCIS and at the same time created more fee
revenue of course.

2. Applicants are left with no information about the progress of their cases
and forced to contact repeatedly the only phone number USCIS provides, which
does not answer any specific questions. The applicants are forced to resort to
other means of contacting the USCIS -- through congressman, senators, and even
whitehouse. Surprisingly, the USCIS does respond to these kind of indirect
inqueries fairly quickly, while taking a long time to respond to direct inquiries.

The funding issue of USCIS should not be solved by raising the fees unfairly
since the exising problems can be solved through technological improvement such
as providing a transparent progress monitor and application-filing system
through web-based software. E-filing some applications is already a reality.
USCIS should extend this service to most applications.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
